title: 114_hr4662
content: The "School-Based Asthma Management Program Act" allows trained school personnel to administer epinephrine and asthma-related rescue medications, giving preference to certain states. Section 399L(d) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to give preference to states that allow trained school personnel to administer epinephrine and asthma-related rescue medications in public schools. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allow trained school personnel to administer epinephrine and asthma-related rescue medications to students in public schools. This includes maintaining a supply of medication and ensuring easy access for administration to students in need. The school must have a secure location for asthma rescue medication and trained personnel for administration. They must also have a school nurse or trained individuals on the premises at all times and a comprehensive asthma management program under the nurse's direction. The asthma management program for schools includes identifying students with asthma, creating individual asthma action plans, providing asthma education for staff, and implementing comprehensive emergency responses. The school's asthma management program includes emergency responses, medication policies, efforts to reduce triggers, and support systems for students with asthma. The school's asthma management program includes providing asthma-related rescue medication to students with asthma and administering epinephrine to students experiencing anaphylactic reactions. The term 'asthma-related rescue medication' refers to short-acting bronchodilators like albuterol and levalbuterol.
